title: Exercises: Greetings and Closings in Emails

items.prompt: Which greeting is best if you do NOT know the person's name?
items.explanation: 'Dear Sir/Madam' is the standard formal greeting when the recipient's name is unknown.

items.prompt: What is the correct formal way to address a man named Robert Smith?
items.explanation: In formal English, we use 'Dear' + 'Mr.' + 'Last Name'.

items.prompt: Which of these is an INFORMAL greeting?
items.explanation: 'Hi [First Name]' is informal and suitable for colleagues you know well.

items.prompt: If you start an email with 'Dear Sir/Madam', what is the most formal closing?
items.explanation: Traditionally, 'Yours faithfully' is used when you don't know the recipient's name.
'Best regards' is a standard professional closing, similar to 'saludos cordiales'.

items.prompt: Which title is used for a woman when you don't know if she is married?
items.explanation: 'Ms.' is the neutral and professional title for women in business.

items.prompt: How do you address a group of colleagues?
items.explanation: 'Hello Everyone' or 'Dear Team' is appropriate for group messages.

items.prompt: Which closing is very informal and common in UK English?
items.explanation: 'Cheers' is a very common informal closing in British English.

items.prompt: If you know the person well, you can use:
items.explanation: Using first names is standard for colleagues with a close relationship.

items.prompt: What is the purpose of a 'Closing' in an email?
items.explanation: A closing is used to end the message in a professional manner.
'Sincerely' or 'Yours sincerely' is highly formal.
The correct spelling is S-I-N-C-E-R-E-L-Y.

items.prompt: When writing to a client for the first time, use:
items.explanation: First contact with a client should always be formal.
'Yours sincerely' is used when you have addressed the person by name.

items.prompt: Which of these is a brief, standard closing?
options: I hope to hear from you soon and have a nice day,
items.explanation: 'Best,' is a common, short, and professional closing.

items.prompt: Is 'Dear Sir' used for a woman?
items.explanation: 'Sir' is for men; 'Madam' is for women.

items.prompt: Which phrase is used to start a very formal letter/email to a company?
items.explanation: 'To whom it may concern' is used when you don't have a specific department or person.
After the greeting, you typically start with an opening sentence like 'I hope you are well'.

items.prompt: Which of these is polite but not too formal?
items.explanation: 'Kind regards' is a polite, widely used professional closing.

items.prompt: In an email to a friend who is also a colleague, you might use:
items.explanation: 'Hi' is perfect for friends/colleagues.
In standard business English, a comma follows the greeting.
'Dear Mr. Jones' is a greeting.
'Kind regards' is a closing.
'Hi John' is a greeting, not a closing.
'Yours faithfully' is a closing.

items.prompt: Is 'Hello!' appropriate for a first-time email to a director?
options: Only if you use an emoji
items.explanation: For a director, a formal 'Dear' greeting is more professional.

items.prompt: What is the common abbreviation for 'Missus' (married woman)?
items.explanation: Mrs. is used for a married woman.

items.prompt: What is the common abbreviation for 'Mister'?
items.explanation: Mr. is the abbreviation for Mister.

items.prompt: Which is more professional for a general closing?
items.explanation: 'Regards' is professional; the others are too casual.
The standard formal opening is 'Dear Sir/Madam'.
'Dear' is used to start formal and semi-formal emails.
'Yours faithfully' is the formal closing when the name is unknown.
'Sincerely' is a formal way to close an email.
'Best regards' is the most common professional closing.
'Hello' can be used for group greetings.
'Hi' is an informal greeting for colleagues.
'Sir' is the formal address for a man.
'Madam' is the formal address for a woman.
'Kind regards' is a very polite professional closing.
'Many thanks' is a brief and polite closing.
'Yours sincerely' is formal when you know the person's name.
'Ms.' is the standard title for women in professional settings.
'Mr.' is the abbreviation for Mister.
'To whom it may concern' is used for very formal, unaddressed messages.
'Thanks for your help' is a polite way to close.

items.explanation: Choice of greeting depends on your relationship with the recipient.

items.prompt: Match the closings with their style:
items.explanation: Closings should match the level of formality of the greeting.

items.prompt: Match the titles with the person:
items.explanation: Titles identify the gender and sometimes marital status of the recipient.

items.explanation: Understanding the Spanish equivalent helps in choosing the right English tone.
A professional email follows a logical sequence of parts.

items.prompt: Match the abbreviations with their full words:
items.explanation: Abbreviations are almost always used in email addresses/headers.

items.prompt: Match the situation with the greeting:
items.explanation: Social distance determines how you open an email.

items.prompt: Match the closing with the starting greeting:
items.explanation: In formal correspondence, there is a traditional 'matching' of opening and closing.
Formality levels range from strictly professional to very casual.

items.explanation: Using the correct title shows respect and attention to detail.

items.title: A Formal Letter
items.text:
Dear Ms. Henderson,

Thank you for your email regarding the new office furniture. I am reviewing the prices now.

Yours sincerely,

David Miller
Procurement Officer

questions.question: Is this email formal or informal?
questions.explanation: The use of 'Dear Ms. Henderson' and 'Yours sincerely' indicates a formal tone.

questions.question: Who is the sender?
questions.explanation: David Miller signed the email at the bottom.

items.title: Email to the Team
items.text:
Hi Everyone,

Just a quick reminder about the meeting at 3:00 PM today. See you there!

Best,

Karen

questions.question: Who is the recipient of this email?
questions.explanation: 'Hi Everyone' is used for a group or team.

questions.question: What is the tone of this email?
questions.explanation: The use of 'Hi', 'quick reminder', and 'Best' is informal and friendly.

items.title: Choosing the Title
items.text: In modern business, 'Ms.' is very popular. You use it for any woman. You don't need to know if she is married or not. For men, we always use 'Mr.'. For doctors or professors, we use 'Dr.' or 'Prof.'.

questions.question: When do you use 'Ms.'?
questions.explanation: The text says 'Ms.' is used for any woman, regardless of marital status.

questions.question: Which title is used for a male teacher at a university?
questions.explanation: The text mentions 'Prof.' for professors.

items.title: Closing Rules
items.text: There are rules for closings. If you start with 'Dear Sir/Madam', use 'Yours faithfully'. If you use the person's name (e.g., 'Dear Mr. Smith'), use 'Yours sincerely'. For most everyday business, 'Best regards' is always a safe choice.

questions.question: What follows 'Dear Sir/Madam'?
questions.explanation: The text explicitly states: 'use Yours faithfully'.

questions.question: What is a 'safe' choice for everyday emails?
questions.explanation: The text says 'Best regards' is a safe choice for most situations.

items.title: A First Contact
items.text:
To whom it may concern,

I am writing to inquire about the job vacancy in the marketing department. I have attached my CV to this email.

Yours faithfully,

Laura Jenkins

questions.question: Why does Laura use 'To whom it may concern'?
options: She doesn't have a specific contact name
She is writing to a friend
questions.explanation: This phrase is used when the specific recipient is unknown.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the email?
questions.explanation: She is writing about a 'job vacancy'.

items.title: Informal Workplace
items.text: At my company, we don't use 'Dear'. We are very informal. I always write 'Hi Tom' or 'Hello team'. For closings, I usually write 'Thanks' or 'Best'. It is faster and more friendly.

questions.question: Does this company use formal greetings?
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'we don't use Dear' and 'we are very informal'.

questions.question: What closings does the speaker use?
questions.explanation: The speaker mentions 'Thanks' or 'Best'.

items.title: The Sign-off
items.text: After the closing, you must sign your name. In a formal email, use your full name (First and Last name). In an informal email, just your first name is okay. Your signature usually includes your job title and phone number too.

questions.question: What should you use in a formal sign-off?
questions.explanation: The text says 'use your full name' for formal emails.

questions.question: Is just the first name okay for informal emails?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'In an informal email, just your first name is okay'.

items.title: Internal vs External
items.text: Greetings change if the email is internal or external. Internal emails are for people in your company. You can use 'Hi'. External emails are for clients or other companies. These should be more formal with 'Dear Mr./Ms.' or 'Dear Sir/Madam'.

questions.question: Who are external emails for?
questions.explanation: External emails are for people outside your organization.

questions.question: What greeting can you use for a colleague in your office?
questions.explanation: 'Hi' is appropriate for internal colleagues.

items.title: Email Punctuation
items.text: In the US, many people use a colon (:) after the greeting in formal emails (e.g., 'Dear Mr. Smith:'). In the UK and for less formal emails, a comma (,) is standard (e.g., 'Dear Mr. Smith,'). Both are professional.

questions.question: What punctuation is common in the US for formal emails?
questions.explanation: The text says 'In the US... use a colon'.

questions.question: Is the comma professional?
questions.explanation: The text says 'Both are professional'.

items.title: Gender-Neutral Business
items.text: If you don't know the gender of a person (for example, the name is 'Chris'), you can write the full name without a title: 'Dear Chris Smith,'. This is very common now to avoid mistakes with Mr. or Ms.

questions.question: What should you do if you don't know the gender?
options: Use the full name without a title
questions.explanation: The text suggests using the full name to avoid gender errors.

questions.question: Is 'Dear Chris Smith,' professional?
questions.explanation: The text says it is 'very common now' in business.

items.title: Listening: A Formal Call
items.transcript: Speaker: When you write to the new client, Mrs. Gable, make sure you use 'Dear Mrs. Gable' in the beginning. And please, don't use 'Best', use 'Sincerely' for the first email.

questions.question: What title should be used for the client?
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'Dear Mrs. Gable'.

questions.question: Which closing is requested?
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'use Sincerely for the first email'.

items.title: Listening: Using Ms.
items.transcript: Speaker: Should I use Mrs. or Miss for the new director? Neither, just use 'Dear Ms. Robertson'. It's more professional and you can't go wrong.

questions.question: Which title is recommended?
questions.explanation: The speaker recommends 'Ms.' as the professional choice.

questions.question: Why is it recommended?

items.title: Listening: UK vs US
items.transcript: Speaker: I'm writing to our London office, so I'll use 'Yours faithfully' since I don't know the name. For our New York office, I usually just use 'Sincerely'.

questions.question: What closing is used for the London office?
questions.explanation: The speaker uses 'Yours faithfully' for London.

questions.question: Why use 'Yours faithfully'?
options: Because it is required by law
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'since I don't know the name'.

items.title: Listening: Brief Closing

questions.question: What is the closing?

questions.question: Is this email internal or external?
questions.explanation: The speaker asks if it's fine for an 'internal message'.

items.title: Listening: Matching Greeting/Closing
items.transcript: Speaker: Remember the rule: if you start with 'Dear Mr. Thompson', you should end with 'Yours sincerely'. Don't mix them up!

questions.question: What is the suggested closing for 'Dear Mr. Thompson'?

questions.question: Who is being addressed?
